content.title: Bronchoscopy
content.summary: Endoscopic procedure allowing direct visualization of airways and sampling of lung tissue or secretions for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes
key_points: Flexible bronchoscopy is the standard approach; rigid bronchoscopy for specific indications
Diagnostic uses: BAL for infections/ILD, transbronchial biopsy, brushings, washings
Therapeutic uses: foreign body removal, stent placement, tumor debulking, bleeding control
BAL returns cells and microorganisms from alveolar spaces for analysis
Transbronchial biopsy samples peripheral lung parenchyma
Complications: bleeding, pneumothorax (1-3% with biopsy), hypoxemia, laryngospasm
Contraindications: severe hypoxemia, bleeding diathesis, unstable cardiovascular status

statement.text: Bronchoscopy is an endoscopic procedure that allows direct visualization of the tracheobronchial tree and sampling of airways and lung tissue. Flexible bronchoscopy is the most common approach, performed with sedation and topical anesthesia. Diagnostic applications include bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) for infections and interstitial lung disease, transbronchial biopsy for peripheral lesions, and direct visualization of endobronchial abnormalities. Therapeutic applications include foreign body removal, airway stent placement, and tumor debulking.
statement.formal: Bronchoscopy = Airway visualization + Sampling (BAL | Biopsy | Brushings) Â± Intervention (FB removal | Stent | Debulking)

explanation.intuition: A bronchoscope is a thin, flexible tube with a camera and working channel that allows pulmonologists to look directly inside the airways, take samples, and perform treatments. It's like a diagnostic and therapeutic 'highway' into the lungs. BAL washes out a segment of lung to collect cells and organisms from deep within the alveoli - useful for diagnosing infections and interstitial diseases. Biopsies sample actual tissue for pathology.
explanation.key_insight: The yield of bronchoscopy depends on lesion location. Central lesions are directly visible and easily biopsied with near 100% yield. Peripheral lesions require fluoroscopic guidance, navigational bronchoscopy, or alternative approaches (CT-guided biopsy) and have lower yield (30-70%). For infections, BAL has higher sensitivity than expectorated sputum because it samples the actual site of disease.
explanation.technical_details: BAL involves wedging the bronchoscope in a subsegmental bronchus and instilling 100-300 mL of saline in aliquots, then recovering the fluid for analysis. Transbronchial biopsy uses forceps passed through the bronchoscope to sample peripheral lung under fluoroscopy. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) with transbronchial needle aspiration (TBNA) allows sampling of mediastinal lymph nodes for cancer staging.

definitions_glossary.bronchoscopy: Endoscopic examination of the tracheobronchial tree using a bronchoscope
definitions_glossary.flexible_bronchoscopy: Standard approach using thin, flexible video bronchoscope under moderate sedation
definitions_glossary.rigid_bronchoscopy: Straight metal tube approach requiring general anesthesia; for foreign bodies, massive hemoptysis, stents
definitions_glossary.bronchoalveolar_lavage: Instillation and aspiration of saline through bronchoscope to sample alveolar contents
definitions_glossary.transbronchial_biopsy: Forceps biopsy of lung parenchyma through the bronchoscope
definitions_glossary.endobronchial_biopsy: Direct biopsy of visible airway lesions
definitions_glossary.bronchial_washing: Collection of secretions from airways by instilling small volume of saline
definitions_glossary.bronchial_brushing: Cytology brush sampling of airway surface for cells
definitions_glossary.endobronchial_ultrasound: EBUS - ultrasound probe in bronchoscope for real-time imaging of structures around airways
definitions_glossary.transbronchial_needle_aspiration: TBNA - needle passed through airway wall to sample mediastinal nodes or masses
definitions_glossary.navigational_bronchoscopy: Electromagnetic or virtual navigation to guide biopsy of peripheral lesions
definitions_glossary.fluoroscopy: Real-time X-ray imaging used to guide transbronchial biopsy

pathophysiology.mechanism: Bronchoscopy exploits the natural airway to access the respiratory system. The flexible bronchoscope is passed through the nose or mouth, through the larynx, and into the tracheobronchial tree. The working channel allows passage of instruments for sampling and intervention. BAL samples the alveolar compartment by flooding and aspirating a lung segment.

sampling_techniques.bal: Wedge scope in subsegment; instill 100-300 mL saline in 20-60 mL aliquots; aspirate and analyze cells, microorganisms, protein
sampling_techniques.transbronchial_biopsy: Forceps passed to periphery under fluoroscopy; sample parenchyma (risk of pneumothorax, bleeding)
sampling_techniques.endobronchial_biopsy: Direct forceps biopsy of visible mucosal abnormalities
sampling_techniques.tbna: Needle through airway wall into lymph nodes or masses (especially with EBUS guidance)
sampling_techniques.brushings: Cytology brush for cells from airway surface

diagnostic: Suspected lung cancer (central or peripheral lesions)

contraindications.absolute: Lack of consent, inadequate facilities/expertise, uncontrollable cough

preparation.medications: Hold anticoagulants per protocol (if biopsy planned)
preparation.labs: Platelet count, INR if biopsy planned

technique.examination: Systematic examination of all accessible airways
technique.sampling: Targeted based on imaging and visual findings

post_procedure.monitoring: 2 hours observation; NPO until gag reflex returns
post_procedure.imaging: Chest X-ray after transbronchial biopsy (check for pneumothorax)
post_procedure.discharge: Same-day if stable; admit for significant complications

complications_management.bleeding: Usually self-limited; cold saline, epinephrine, bronchial blocker if severe
complications_management.pneumothorax: Observe small (<15%); chest tube if large or symptomatic
complications_management.hypoxemia: Supplemental O2; may need to abort procedure
complications_management.bronchospasm: Inhaled bronchodilators; systemic steroids if severe

definition.@value: Endoscopic procedure for direct visualization of airways and sampling of lung tissue or secretions for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes

skos.scopeNote: Covers flexible bronchoscopy techniques including BAL, transbronchial biopsy, and EBUS; rigid bronchoscopy mentioned briefly
skos.example: A 60-year-old smoker with lung mass on CT undergoes EBUS with TBNA of mediastinal lymph nodes for lung cancer staging; cytology confirms adenocarcinoma with N2 nodal involvement

learning_objectives: List diagnostic and therapeutic indications for bronchoscopy
Compare BAL, transbronchial biopsy, and EBUS-TBNA sampling techniques
Describe proper patient preparation and post-procedure care
Interpret BAL results for common conditions
clinical_pearls: BAL is best for diffuse lung disease and infections; biopsy for focal lesions
Transbronchial biopsy has ~3% pneumothorax rate - always get post-procedure CXR
EBUS-TBNA has replaced mediastinoscopy for lung cancer staging in many centers
Fever after BAL is common (transient) - doesn't necessarily indicate infection
Yield for peripheral lesions is low (30-40%) without navigational guidance
Rigid bronchoscopy for massive hemoptysis, large foreign bodies, or tracheal tumors

board_yield.pulmonology_boards: Very High - technique details, diagnostic interpretation

common_misconceptions: Bronchoscopy can reach all parts of the lung (false - limited to airways >2mm)
BAL is just for infections (false - also useful for ILD, alveolar proteinosis, eosinophilia)
Biopsy is needed for all diagnoses (false - BAL alone may be diagnostic)
Bronchoscopy is contraindicated in hypoxemia (false - relative contraindication; can be done carefully with supplemental O2)
